data.title: Henry John (Deutschendorf) Denver Jr (1943-1997)

data.text:
Ancestors

Husband of [private wife (1940s - unknown)]

[children unknown]

Profile last modified 8 Jul 2024 | Created 22 Nov 2014

This page has been accessed 7,243 times.

Biography

John (Deutschendorf) Denver Jr is Notable.

John Denver was a noted American singer/songwriter, activist, and humanitarian.

An evening with John Denver

Henry John Deutschendorf was born on December 31, 1943 in Roswell, New Mexico, son of Henry John Deutschendorf and Erma Louise Swope.[1][2]

He was nicknamed "Jitterbug" when he was young and had boundless energy and loved to perform. His mother insisted he pronounce words when he was singing, so everyone could understand the song. His parents captured home movie footage of his performances. The family said John was an amazing story teller.[3]

At age 12, his grandmother gave him a guitar she has played and he began guitar lessons in Tucson, Arizona.[4]

Some of John's best childhood memories were on his father's hometown farm in Oklahoma. John worked wheat harvest with the family relatives and the memories gave inspiration to future songs.[4]

John attended Arlington Heights High School, in Ft Worth, Texas, United States.[5]

In 1963, he moved to Los Angeles and changed his name from Henry John Deutschendorf, Jr. to John Denver for his recording career. He took his new last name from the capital of his favorite state of Colorado, where he later resided in Aspen.[6]

John married first in 1967.[7][8][9][10] John's second marriage to an Australian actress, was in 1988.[11]

He moved to Colorado in 1970, and the beauty of nature around him energized his song writing.[4] John first gained recognition as a songwriter with “Leaving On A Jet Plane” which was recorded by Peter, Paul and Mary (their first and only number one hit). He became a top music star in the 1970s with hits: “Take Me Home, Country Roads,” “Rocky Mountain High,” “Sunshine On My Shoulders,” “Annie’s Song,” “Back Home Again,” “Thank God I’m A Country Boy,” and “Calypso”.[6]

In 1985, he was invited to perform in the USSR, which lead to a concert tour there in 1986. John returned again to USSR in 1987 for a concert to benefit the he victims of Chernobyl.[6] He memorized a verse of "Annie's Song" in Russian to sing at the concerts, which helped establish rapport with his audience.[3]

John cared deeply about world peace, hunger, and protecting the environment. He focused on world-hunger concerts.[3]

John died on October 12, 1997 in Monterey Bay near Pacific Grove, California, aged 53.[1][12][13][14]

John Denver "Spirit" statue

Deutschendorf ~ West Prussia to German-Russian Roots

The name is pronounced in various ways by family members today, usually "Dutchen-dorf but sometimes "Deutschen-dorf." The name "Deutschendorf literally means "German village."

In his autobiography, John Denver references the Deutschendorfs in Oklahoma, who were Germans from Russia. In his book, John shares family folklore, and describes the early Deutschendorfs as "a pretty impressive band of people .,. [who] worked for themselves the entire four seasons, and they worked hard.[15] His paternal grandparents were immigrants who were Black Sea Germans from Mennonite colonies.

His ancestors emmigrated from Kuckuck (Thiensdorf), West Prussia and settled in South Russia (some areas now Ukraine). They made their home in Ekaterinoslav region before moving to North Caucasus, where many Black Sea Germans and Volga Germans merged for farm land and migration from war.

On June 19,1998, a special "Memorial Tribute to John Denver" was held at the AHSGR Convention in Wichita, Kansas. John's mother Erma and other cousins attended. AHSGR dedicated a brick in their Lincoln, Nebraska pioneers memorial which bears a musical symbol, and includes this inscription; JOHN DENVER 1943—1997.[15]

Name: Henry John Deutschendorf "Denver" Jr; Death Date: 13 Oct 1997; Death Place: Monterey Bay, Monterey, California; Obituary Date: 13 Oct 1997; Obituary Place: Washington, United States; Birth Date: 1944; Birth Place: Roswell, , New Mexico; Source Newspaper: Seattle Times, The; Relationship To Head: Deceased; Age: 53; System Of Record: SLS.

↑ 15.0 15.1 Germans from Russia: Kloberdanz, Dr. Timothy J. "Henry John Deutschendorf, Jr.: The World Knew Him as John Denver." Journal of the American Historical Society of Germans from Russia 21 (1998): 1–5.: John Denver's Take Me Home: An Autobiography. (New York: Harmony Books, 1994). Kloberdanz note: Ibid, pp. 2-4. John Denver describes his Deutschendorf grandparents as "Germans from the Volga River," But it is doubtful if his ancestors were indeed Volga Germans. Confusion may have resulted because the Deutschendorfs lived in close proximity to Volga Germans both in Russia (North Caucasus) and later in western Oklahoma (Washita County).

Passenger List: "Washington, U.S., Arriving and Departing Passenger and Crew Lists, 1882-1965"
